review.title: Unified vector space mapping for knowledge representation systems
review.abstract: One of the most significant problems which inhibits further developments in the areas of Knowledge Representation and Artificial Intelligence is a problem of semantic alignment or knowledge mapping. The progress in its solution will be greatly beneficial for further advances of information retrieval, ontology alignment, relevance calculation, text mining, natural language processing etc. In the paper the concept of multidimensional global knowledge map, elaborated through unsupervised extraction of dependencies from large documents corpus, is proposed. In addition, the problem of direct Human - Knowledge Representation System interface is addressed and a concept of adaptive decoder proposed for the purpose of interaction with previously described unified mapping model. In combination these two approaches are suggested as basis for a development of a new generation of knowledge representation systems.

metadata.title: Unified vector space mapping for knowledge representation systems

sections.text: Abstract One of the most important problems hindering further developments in the fields of knowledge representation and artificial intelligence is the problem of semantic alignment or knowledge mapping. The progress of its solution will be of great benefit for further advances in the fields of information gathering, ontology alignment, relevance calculation, text mining, natural language processing, etc. The paper proposes the concept of the multidimensional global knowledge map, which is elaborated by uncontrolled extraction of dependencies from large document corpus. Furthermore, the problem of the direct interface between human and knowledge is addressed and a concept of the adaptive decoder is proposed for the purpose of interacting with the previously described uniform mapping models. In combination, these two approaches are proposed as the basis for the development of a new generation of knowledge representation systems.

sections.heading: 2.2 The concept of a Global Knowledge Map (GKM)
sections.text: We believe that it is possible to elaborate a single standard for mapping knowledge by constructing a logical space with the aim of projecting specific knowledge concepts of the real world. Such a model (let's call it "Global Knowledge Map") should reflect the level of similarity of documents and concepts. Therefore, the main purpose of the model is that it requires a mathematical / logical model of knowledge retention with a specific condition: it is optimal for the task of knowledge representation, i.e. interaction with man. To fulfil this condition, the model must reflect the structure of human knowledge in its dimensionality or structure.

sections.heading: 3.1 Ideal knowledge representation interface
sections.text: The interface part of the Knowledge Representation System is important when discussing the ideal system. Both the tasks of receiving requests from users and the transmission of knowledge to them are of equal importance as the tasks of data structuring and storage. In the current work, we discuss the paths towards a new generation of Knowledge Representation Systems and therefore the question of interaction is overlooked to determine whether it is possible to provide an idealistic interface by means of modern technology. "The interfaces used to support the interaction of a human user with modern knowledge representation systems and information retrieval systems are mainly of the" indexing "type, i.e. users need to know exactly what they are looking for, and they also need to specify it linguistically. a common example of such an interface is a search engine. As we have mentioned above, search engine and the corpus of WW documents are the most complete and up-to-date knowledge representation systems available nowadays, and this is considered to be the reason for their popularity, but at the same time it is a very simple problem for their use.

sections.heading: 3.2 High dimensionality and visualisation
sections.text: After mentioning that the resulting global mapping space is likely to be n-dimensional, where n is high, it is necessary to solve the problem of visual representation. It is possible for humans to imagine the 3D space, so the optimal ways of nD- > 3D representation need to be evaluated. Dimensionality reduction techniques or a multiple representation approach via interface could be applied. It is important that with the help of the unified knowledge mapping space, the error in calculating the relevance between documents is minimized and furthermore, retrieving relevant documents from other systems becomes a trivial task. For the end user, this means that once the system has found the topic in which he / she is interested, the user will never lead to irrelevant documents.
